author: Banjinbuban

title: X-carve Dewalt DWP611 Router Bottom Wood Dust Control Cap

description.text:
Design criteria:

  1. Use existing fan mechanism.
  2. No modifications to existing housing, motor, lighting, etc..
  3. Use air flow to control where wood dust goes.
  4. Maximize wood dust removal from tool paths.
  5. Minimize cleanup.
  6. Work with existing vacuum boot.

Did I miss anything?

Using the existing cooling fan air flow I designed the router bottom cap to put two jets of air behind the tool and on either side. This blows wood dust forward. I put the rest of the air flow into two plenums that blow horizontally out the front and toward the vacuum system inlet.

I made the center locator diameter tight and used hot water to make the PLA pliable before pressing it on. This ensures a perfect fit.

I found two screws in my screw stash with the same diameter and pitch as the existing screws. I ground them to about 4mm longer than the existing screws. The mount is 4mm thick.

The cap does narrow the light cones from the LEDs.

I tested the design and it completely cleans out the tool paths and directs almost all of the wood dust into the vacuum system. 99% maybe more.

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Motor Mount Replacement (with Z Axis REAL Fix)

title: Anet A8 1-piece Z motor mount v3

description.text:
Okay so this is my first contribution.. On version 3 already. I started by virtually assembling each piece, and filling in the holes for hardware, and the gaps between the tabs. I put a front face on them, I hid the screw holes on the sides and top, I added "Anet A8" lettering / venting, removed the overhang, and put a 45 degree edge on the corners. The lines showing up on the face of the print is from the gap in the tape as these have to be printed face down. Consider that when you print these.. glass or a buildtak mat is probably the way to go here.

I used a gas station rewards card and cut a slot in it to set the couplers, as seen in the 2nd pic. Also during install, leave the motors a little loose and get the lead screws to line up nicely before you fully tighten the motor to the mount.

Edit: As of 8/29/17, this is done being tweeked. It fits and works as it should, so unless someone brings something to my attention that I'm not aware of (doubtful) this is complete and finalized.

Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: Lantis
remixed_from.title: Pi Zero Camera Mount for CR10

title: D-Bot V-Slot Pi Zero W Camera Mount

description.text:
Remixed a great design by Lantis and made it a so that it can be mounted to the top front rail of the D-Bot printer for a downward view of the build plate.

Stays nicely out of the way.

M3 screw and nut to attach ball joint to pi case.
2x M5 screws and square nuts (you know the one) to attach pi case to frame.

Initial issues:

  • The mounts for the M5 to rail are a little thin - I used 3xM5 washers to accommodate - this can easily be remixed to increase the depth...I'm just too lazy.

  • Would definitely benefit from the standard v-slot rail guide added to the bottom although that would make it really ugly to print...lots of supports required. Works fine without and tightened.

NOTE: When installing the pi/camera - best to run the camera cable through the case first, then attach to pi board and then slide the pi in place (you'll need to remove the SD card and install it after the pi is in place).

Update: If your cable chain is touching the camera on long builds, I've uploaded an alternate back cover where the camera can be mounted on the outside edge of the case. I've also included an alternate arm that will bring the camera closer to the middle of the pi case with the alternate back cover. The second set of photos show this in action.

author: fritztoch

print_settings.Notes:: For pinions and gears I am used 1.75mm POM Filament

description.text:
Adapting SEBEN EQ3 telescope mount to OnStep Goto system by Howard Dutton project.
More info on website http://www.stellarjourney.com/index.php?r=site/equipment_onstep

How to this working? See my video: https://youtu.be/mOXqw7EN8YE

FreeCAD sources on Github

My Wiring Diagram on EasyEDA

Infill:

POM 25%, ABS 50%

Notes:
  • For pinions and gears I am used 1.75mm POM Filament
  • For other thing I am used 1.75mm ABS Filament

For SEBEN EQ3 I am detected this parmeters:
RA axis: primary worm screw transver raito is 138:1
DEC axis: primary worm screw transver raito is 88:1

In my 1st version I am used Nema 17 Stepper motor without gear box
(The pinions has 16 teeth and an 6mm hole, gear for both axes have 54 teeth)

OnStep Arduino firmware config.h parameters is:

// Axis1 is for RA/Az
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis1   4140.0 
// calculated as: stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360                   
// NEMA 17 :  200   * 16   * 54/16   *  138/360  =  4140.0

// Axis2 is for Dec/Alt                                   
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis2   2640.0
// calculated as: stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360
// NEMA 17  :  200  * 16  *  54/16  *  88/360  =  2640.0

// PEC, number of steps for a complete worm rotation 
#define StepsPerWormRotationAxis1 10800L
//(StepsPerDegreeAxis1*360)/gear_reduction2.
// (4140*360)/138 = 10800

These stepper motors during operation is very hot :-(

In the 2nd version I am used stepper motors with planetary gear box . The new stepper motors have gear box with ratio 3.71: 1 (The pinions has 16 teeth and an 8mm hole, gear for both axes have 54 teeth)

OnStep Arduino firmware config.h parameters is:

// Axis1 is for RA/Az
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis1  15359.4 
// calculated as: stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360
// NEMA17 + PLANET  :  200  *  16  *  3.71*54/16  * 138/360  = 15359.4

// Axis2 is for Dec/Alt
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis2   9794.4 
// calculated as: stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360
// NEMA17 + PLANET  :  200  * 16  * 3.71*54/16  *  88/360    = 9794.4

// PEC, number of steps for a complete worm rotation (in RA), 
#define StepsPerWormRotationAxis1 40068L
//  (StepsPerDegreeAxis1*360)/gear_reduction2
//  (15359*360)/138 = 40068L

Alternatively can be used stepper motors with planetary gears box with ratio (5+2/11) : 1
(The pinions has 16 teeth and an 8mm hole, gear for RA axis have 55 teeth and gear for DEC axsi have 54 teeth)
OnStep Arduino firmware config.h parameters is (NOT TESTED) :

// Axis1 is for RA/Az
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis1   21850.0   
// calculated as :  stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360                                 
// (5+2/11):1      :  200  * 16   * (5+2/11) * 55/16  *  138/360  =  21850.0

// Axis2 is for Dec/Alt                                     
#define StepsPerDegreeAxis2   13680.0
// calculated as:  stepper_steps * micro_steps * gear_reduction1 * gear_reduction2/360
// (5+2/11):1     :  200  * 16 * (5+2/11) * 54/16  *  88/360   = 13680.0                                   

// PEC, number of steps for a complete worm rotation (in RA)
#define StepsPerWormRotationAxis1 57000L
// (StepsPerDegreeAxis1*360)/gear_reduction2.
// (21850*360)/138= 57000

My full config.h is included for OnStep alpha version 27-Jul-2017 on github

title: Simply Backing Z (A simple rear mount Z brace) 5/16th Version

description.text:
This is a much more minimalist take on the rear Z brace. This is an improvement on my previous design listed in the remix section. This brace takes less material, print time, and hardware. In return you get much more stiff and robust brace when compared to my first brace. With this being a minimalist take I have removed the non essentials including even brace feet. This does mean that you have to keep the printer on a level surface as you would without a brace. I have already checked and my printer is able to move up without anything forcefully interacting with the angled rods. I have added stuff like Z extensions and scraper holders.

As always I would really appreciate it if you guys could leave a make any feedback you can think of. Thanks for reading!!!!

Now producing and selling kits of this design on etsy and ebay. These kits include the hardware and printed components. We can always just sell the hardware by itself if that interests you. I relisted the only kit I have left on hand for this brace set, I have a couple more kits with 3/8th hardware. https://www.etsy.com/listing/565451525/3d-printer-parts-simply-backing-z-a?ref=listing_published_alert

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed all the parts seen above with 30% infill and 3 shells or perimeters. I did not use supports or rafts.

This brace uses 5/16th hardware, check out the 3/8th version if you have that hardware.

Edit: I updated the brace so in theory it needs even less rod than initial release, but I will still recommend 16 inches as it's a good square number.

2X 5/16th rods 16 inches long
2X 5/16th locknuts
6X 5/16th normal nuts
8X M3 by 10mm long hex screws
and the printed parts on this page.

description.header: How I install the non extended brace
description.text:
The video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d8O52lV3W18
I have included a video on this, however I will also list it here.

after you have all the hardware needed you can start installing the brace.

  1. Slip a normal nut onto the rod followed by the back leg and finished off with a locknut. I make the rod end flush with the locknut bottom.
  2. Remove the two screws from the back of the printer where the back leg will be attached. Leave the middle screw in place.
  3. Screw the back leg onto the printer and make sure it's securely attached.
  4. Remove the two side screws from the printer.
  5. Screw another nut onto the rod and I recommend screwing it pretty far down to keep it out of the way.
  6. Time to add the tower connector and screw it onto the printer.
  7. Add the final normal nut onto the rod above the tower connection.
  8. Time to tighten everything up. I do the bottom leg first, than adjust the top to keep all the printer rods perpendicular .
Step one. Step two. Step three. Step four. Step five. Step six. Step seven. Step eight. Step eight.

Back_right_leg.stl : Holds the rod to the back of the printer and connects with two screw holes
Back_left_leg.stl : Holds the rod to the back of the printer and connects with two screw holes
Left_tower_conection.stl : Holds the rod to the side of the printer and connects with two screw holes.
Right_tower_conection.stl : Holds the rod to the side of the printer and connects with two screw holes.
NutCover.stl : Covers the nuts used in the brace can cover a locknut if needed.
Full_plate.stl : All the parts needed for the brace pre laid out for printing
Left_tower_scraperholder.stl : Holds not only the rod to the side of the printer, but also has an included hook for the scraper holder as well. Fits to left side when looking at the front of the machine.
Right_tower_scraperholder.stl : Holds not only the rod to the side of the printer, but also has an included hook for the scraper holder as well. Fits to right side when looking at the front of the machine.
Left_tower_extension_connection.stl : Not only holds the rod to the side of the printer, but it also holds the top sheet metal of the printer up higher. Fits to the left side when looking at the front of the machine.
Right_tower_extension_connection.stl : Not only holds the rod to the side of the printer, but it also holds the top sheet metal of the printer up higher. Fits to the right side when looking at the front of the machine.
Left_tower_extension_scrapperholder_connection.stl : Not only holds the rod to the side of the printer, but it also holds the top sheet metal of the printer up higher and has a scrapper holder incorporated as well. Fits to the left side when looking at the front of the machine.
Right_tower_extension_scrapperholder_connection.stl : Not only holds the rod to the side of the printer, but it also holds the top sheet metal of the printer up higher and has a scrapper holder incorporated as well. Fits to the right side when looking at the front of the machine.

What I have planned and why the page is still a work in progress.

So I have planned updates for this new line of brace and I figured I would list them here.

Nothing here now, feel free to leave suggestions in the comments

Finished Updates

  1. Angle rod holders so that nut covers make full contact. This is a thing that people have been requesting. I will work on it, but the brace works fine as is. It's essentially a major redo and will take a while to do. Additional changes includes adding a cavity within the bottom feet that now hides the lock nut from view and allows better connection between the nut and printed part.

  2. Scraper holder addition, so you can put the scraper on the machine when not in use.

  3. Z extension so we can print higher without fear of the top sheet metal piece.

As I change or update the stuff on the page I will list the changes here.

01/07/2018 : Relisted the last kit I have on hand and put the link up above.
01/07/2018 : Removed the link to the kits for sale as the listing ran out of time. I need to relist the kits.
10/17/2017 : Added a link above to our etsy listing of this design.
10/07/2017 : Added three png files of an installation guide. This guide just repeats what was listed above, but it's meant as a printable guide. This way an online and paper guide can be had.
9/03/2017 : Added the Z extension files and pictures onto the page. Also updated the brace installation pictures to use the current parts.
8/24/2017 : Added two new files on the page. These are tower connectors with built in scraper holders. I have included both sides, so you can choose which side you want the scraper on. I have also included some pictures of the left side as well. They will look the same so I see no point to post pictures of both sides. The main camera is on vacation at the moment, so I had to use the less good back up.
8/17/2017 : Added a new front page picture.
8/15/2017 : Updated files, pictures, and text boxes on page. Uploaded new leg and tower connectors along with a new full plate.
Back_right_leg.stl, Back_left_leg.stl, Left_tower_conection.stl, Right_tower_conection.stl, and Full_plate.stl all updated. Update reasons can be found in the planned update section of this page. Unplanned changes include that now the bottom locknut is now hidden with in the bottom leg.

comments.text: I am assuming you mean something like the Z Extensions from AzzA, if I am wrong please correct me. I added some longer side pieces for extending the top sheet metal lid a while ago. comments.author: Gwarguts

comments.text: Great design! I noticed your printer doesn't have feets like the other z braces mods. Do you feel they're unnecessary to have?
comments.author: cannonstar

comments.text: I think that it overall depends on the printer environment. I think that having adjustable feet can be useful, but only if the user has the printer in an environment that would benefit from them. I decided that I as a user would not need adjustable feet when it came to the final resting spot of my printer. I was also trying to create a minimalist or simple design. By removing printed feet and using the printers stock feet I removed more material usage,print time ,lowered hardware amount needed ,and lowered the amount of printed parts needed. In return of the positives that I get from creating a minimalist design, the negative is that it excludes those that do happen to find adjustable feet necessary. So overall I think they can be necessary, but don't always have to be necessary. Thanks for asking and if you have anymore questions feel free to ask!!
comments.author: cannonstar

comments.text:
I made this, very happy with the results. I use the version that extends the Z axis. I added 1.4mm washers, 8 pieces, to make up for the sheet metal thickness (on the top holes of the tower connections and on the bottom holes of the z axis acme screw brackets). I notice an interference between the cable carrier (the one along the z axis) and the threaded rod, do you think it will be an issue?
I need to learn now how to align the axis, i am afraid i misaligned them. Thanks for your design!
comments.author: oj_

comments.text: Glad to hear that you were happy with the design. Feel free to post a make of the design if you want. I noticed the cable chain when I was working on the design. On my machine at least, I found the chain to be connected to the bottom of the frame with one screw. The cable chain could also freely move or pivot around the screw.I found this to make install of the brace easy and more importantly the cable chain is not being forced into the brace rod with any force. While the chain does have contact with the brace rod, I have not noticed any wear on my cable chain.

remixed_from.title: Fan Mount for new FLSUN Prusa I3

description.text:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2372783

Added another fan remix. Change the blow hole to a smaller circle, seemed to make a big difference.

Replaces the flsun 2017 carriage, adds 3 mounting spots for 40mm cooling fans. I used m3 screws and nuts to hold everything together. It should work with e3d v5 extruder. Tried to work in a belt tension on the carriage but it was easier to just to pull , zip tie, and add a belt tension clip.

Most of the code is re-used from Ferjerez's business card, I added an extra line so you can easily add your job title to the card. To customize, open the .scad file and change the variable values to your own name, title and contact info. Change the seed value to get different subdivision designs.
Expanded battery door for the Nerf Rayven and 3s battery. Make sure to cut out the left side of the tray to fit the battery. This was designed to fit a Turnigy Bolt 1000mAh lipo

title: FL3D Trigger Guard for Evolve GT-ONE-GTX

description.text:
The Trigger Guard for Evolve GT, One, and GTX remotes is designed to protect the rider from those unforeseen or accidental hits of the trigger. The Trigger Guard snap fits directly onto your remote. Toss your remote into a jacket pocket while you stop off at the store, or set your remote down without worrying about launching your board into the wall or out into traffic.

We recommend using ABS, at or near 100% infill. You will need supports. After printing, you'll definitely want to scrape all rough areas left by supports clean, and sand those areas smooth to avoid scratching up your remote with the inside of the guard. We also recommend an acetone vapor bath to further smooth the part to avoid damaging your remote, but if you're ok with with marks on your remote, this might be optional.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Infill:

100

We always scrape the rough areas left by the support material clean, and sand those areas smooth. This is to avoid scratching your remote with the inside of the guard. We also always use an acetone vapor bath to further smooth the guard to avoid scratching.

description.text:
UPDATE JAN 2018: Just beware this design (and the original for that matter) should be loaded with care. Recently I hand wound a 50m loose roll onto the spool to ensure no hitches and must have wound a little too tight in places. This resulted in a jam enough to cause an unattended print to fail. The spool itself rolls very nicely on a metal bar, so that wasn't the issue.

I wanted a larger diameter filament spool than Christoph Laimer's original Unlockable Filament Spool design for larger rolls of loose 2.85mm dia PLA filament.

After printing some sections of Christoph's design to get a feel for the clip and spring features, I experimented with modifying a few features:

  • incorporation of smaller snap-fit features similar to those I'd used on a previous design,
  • thinning the Disk arms to reduce material a little (this turned out to be probably necessary, to enable the arms to snap over the clip features),
  • the original spring features of the Spike-retainer axle-clips on the Fork part were single walled outlines when sliced by Simplify3D v3.0.2, so they were beefed up considerably.

The smaller snap fit features work very well - just don't expect to be able to disassemble this spool as easily as the original.

To assemble, insert each Fork's inner clip in its corresponding mount hole in a Disk arm and gently flex each arm over the outer clip. When the second Disk is finally fitted, the arms really have considerable tension to overcome to snap the outer clips in place - strong fingers or a clamp will be required, but the sound is very satisfying - enjoy!

title: Taz 5 Multi Filament Hot End Assembly Remix

description.text:
This is an ongoing project and some parts may not be available just yet.

This is a remix of two hot end assemblies. One being the original Taz 5 Assembly, the second being the new Prusa MK2 MMU multi-filament hotend that isn't shipping from Prusa till November. This essentially is a quad bowden that feeds into one hotend. using Prusa's Stepper motor multiplexer you can turn the E0 stepper signals into E0-E3 and print multicolor (4 Color) parts rather than utilizing (Pause, unload, reload, resume) techniques.

As referenced here: http://shop.prusa3d.com/en/printer-upgrades/118-original-prusa-i3-mk2-multi-material-upgrade.html

This hotend assembly takes:

1.75mm E3D V6 bowden style all metal hotend
3 X M3 (5mm x 5mm OD) Brass threaded inserts
5 X M3 x 15mm Hex Head Screws
1 X M3 x 30mm Hex Head Screws
3 X M3 Square Nuts
Small legnth of PTFE tubing to mate Y-Splitter to E3D V6 hotend

Additional hardware is needed for the assembly, metal insert tubes and brass threaded inserts for the y-splitter assembly, and hardware associated with the hot end cooling fan and the fan used in active cooling, but I haven't been able to source these yet.

EDIT: After some reading I found an article (not by Prusa) stating that the hotend is not a regualr E3D V6 hot end, but rather a specially modified version that has a special heatbreak tubing that goes between the y-splitter and hotend that is bored to 1.9mm ID and flared out on the ends to reshape the retracted filament, and the steel tubes are 1.85mm ID to aid in cooling the filament after retraction and prevent sticking. If nothing else eventually we should be able to buy replacement parts for the MK2-MMU such as any special hotend, tubing, y-splitter.

I am currently working on modified mounts for the extruder motors, once I have them completed, I'll add all printable parts for the conversion.

Likely Additional Requirements:
Prusa's Super Switch board that turns the RAMBo's E0's stepper signals into a signal that drives steppers 1-4, currently this is not for sale, probably will not be till launch anyways.

Use a modified version of Prusa's Firmware (modified for Taz's bed size, thermistors, etc.)

Use the P.I.N.D.A sensor that Prusa uses (Proximity Sensor) for bed leveling/correction of "(ALL THREE AXIS)" not just Z. Corrects out of square Y/X axis also.

Between the bed heater and the borosilicate glass there are (9) 8mm round copper Sensor points distributed on the bed for axis correction (XYZ). Probe coordinates will need to be edited in firmware to accommodate larger bed.

title: Universal Delta 2020 Spool holder / Filament support, supportless and screwless

description.text:
Hi !

This is my new UNIVERSAL 2020 spool holder / filament spool support,

It can be printed without any support
It can also be used without any screws!
Even the universal ROD can be printed too :p
Can be used on ALL 2020 delta/kossel printers of any size
There is a small slot under the foot to let any cable pass under

INSTRUCTIONS :
-Print 1x SupportLEFT, 1x SupportRIGHT, 2x FootBOTTOM, 2x FootTOP, 8x Pin
-Assemble all parts
-Put them on your printer
-Measure the size of the ROD you will need
-For exemple if you need a 200mm rod, import the ROD stl in your slicer, and set the print height stop to 200mm and print the rod
(the rod is not a simple round object because it's stronger like this)

And VOILA, you have a 100% printed spool holder :p

Please, if you download this object put a Like on this thing :p (or if you have too much money think to tip :p

If you have any ideas or suggestions, contact me here :p

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA. So far no issues but the extruder mount is quite close to the hot end so ABS would be better,

title: ANET A8 2020 X Axis with Titan Aero BLTouch

description.text:
This is a remix of the quoted Anet A8 2020 X axis which works well for the idlers, motor mount and belt tensioner.

I have added my own designs for a quick release gantry based on Openbuilds mini gantry and mini wheels together with a mount for my Titan Aero clone with fan and BLTouch sensor. I have have a modified fan duct and X limit switch.

Note this is designed for the TriangeLabs Titan Aero clone with pancake motor which saves a lot of weight and space. It also gives more vertical height than the original 2 rod setup.

Although this was designed for my AM8, it should work fine with the original design too.

Mechanical Parts

500mm 2020 T/V slot aluminium extrusion.
Openbuilds mini wheels set.
Various M3 nuts and bolts from Anet A8.
Existing 2 x bearings, fan, belt and pulleys from A8
M5 T nuts and bolts for securing printed parts to the extrusion.

Assembly

Follow the original design for the 2020 idlers, motor mount and belt tensioner. Print out the parts for the gantry, extruder mount, fan duct and X limit switch holder. The extruder mount should slide over the mounting joint on the ganrty. If its tight, file it down a bit. If it's loose, you can put a piece of paper between the joints to secure it.

BLTouch Offsets

TBD

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Support is only required for extruder mount if you printer briding is good. Otherwise, might need support for all pieces except the X limit mount.

100% infill recommended for all parts as most are structural in nature.

I used PLA. So far no issues but the extruder mount is quite close to the hot end so ABS would be better,

description.text: A pendent of the constellation Lyra.

This is a battery cover for a 19.2V DieHard rechargable battery for the line of power tools. The contacts of the DieHard battery are recessed, so this isn't as necessary as for the Ryobi from which I remixed this. But I think a cover might keep gunk from getting in.
I designed this for my father-in-law; he has Sears power tools that I think are the DieHard 19.2V series. (I happened to find this battery in the recycling bin at my local Lowe's; it was convenient to have an actual battery to test out.)
The Ryobi cover actually fit pretty well, but it was a bit small: I used the slotted version, and the slot widened a little; I figure this will eventually fatigue the plastic. Also, it needed a slot on a different face to fit properly because the DieHard batteries have a ridge on the shaft. I've uploaded two versions; the _1r version has one internal rib and the _4r has four. The ribs taper as they come up from the bottom, so they only grab the battery when they're on all the way.

description.text:
This is the flintlock and trigger for an India Pattern Brown Bess rifle. This was made so that we could inexpensively arm a bunch of background soldiers in one of our plays.

They're simplified so that I could print them easily on my Printrbot PLA - I wasn't worried about perfect accuracy as our closest audience member was probably twenty feet away from these characters and they were just nameless spear carriers anyway.

The plates are designed to be fastened down with drywall screws and the hammer is held to the plate by a 1/4-20 flathead machine screw and bolt. You will need to assemble and glue the pieces once they're printed. The hammer can be moved, but due to time constraints the pan and frizzen are one solid piece.

title: PCB effector for Diamond Hotend/E3D v6 groove mount + various related parts

description.text:
This is my version of PCB effector and carriage, inspired by dc42's PCB effector. The differences are:

  • Bare PCB, without any electronics.
  • M4 holes for the magnetic balls instead of M3.
  • 60mm arm space.
  • 2mm thickness

To create the PCB

Use the attached dxf files to define the PCBs' outline. The PCBs were made by EasyEDA by importing the DXF files to their PCB edtior to define the border outline. Texts and graphics were added using the editor.

To mount the Diamond hotend

Use the modified Kharar's cooler's shield provided. You need both diamond-on-pcb-effector.scad and Diamond_hotend_shield_no_mount.csg.

To mount the E3D v6 or clone's groove mount

Use 3 PCBs stacking in the different angles. It's a tight fit.

Rod-end

They should be printed upside-down (with the magnetic side up).

My build

  • I'm using RobotDigg's carbon tube. 450mm/5mm/8mm.

  • Magnetics + balls from 3D_HOME/AliExpress. They have M4 hole, so you'll need 12 x M4 screws + 12 x M4 nyloc nut nuts.

author: Puddlefist

print_settings.Notes:: Very fast print time (under 10 min)

title: Pen plotter - draw on paper or create pcbs  Zonestar p802 (v2)

description.text:
This is a pen holder I made quickly in Fusion 360. It holds pens with ~10mm diameter and is installed instead of the proximity sensor on the right side of the extruder. This allows for fast switching between regular printing and pen holder mode. You can use it to create pcbs by using a marker to draw on the areas that should be copper after etching. Alternatively you can just use paper to test it.

The screw and nut are m3.

Recommended settings to use in your slicer:

  • z-hop/z-lift: 1-2mm
  • add z lift after printing to prevent unwanted lines
  • use a small nozzle size that is similar to the width of your pen (I used 0.2mm in the example)
  • print only one layer

Important: enable the "Dry Run" mode in the debugging menu of your printer to disable hotbed and extruder

To create drawings I did the following:

  1. get a black/white image of something ( I used the drawings feature of fusion 360, to create a drawing of this holder)
  2. use inkscape to create a path of the image (Path -> trace bitmap)
  3. export as svg and import in fusion 360, blender or your cad software
  4. extrude the inner parts and export as stl

If you need different diameter holders, write a comment and I make them. This fits on the Zonestar p802 series.

Printer:

Zonestar P802

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

min 30%

Notes:
  • Very fast print time (under 10 min)
  • Print without support for the holes

Updated version 2:

  • added holder for the proximity sensor
  • added adapter for smaller pens

remixed_from.title: GT2 Pulley and Uprated XY Tensioner for Wilson II 3D Printer

description.text:
Redesigned vchan3m's tensioner to make it stronger as well as easier to print for larger nozzles. I am using a 16 toothed idler for better torque. But larger idlers or bearings will fit as well.

It uses an m3 x 20mm screw to hold the idler. Which is secured by an m3 nut.

An m3 x 20mm screw is used to adjust the tension. Just like the original Wilson 2 Y tensioner. If you print w/ a large nozzle you may need to heat up the m3 nut for it to slide down the hole.

An M4 x 25mm and M4 nut is required to secure the tensioner to the Y Idler.

print_settings.Notes:: Mine was printed in Hatchbox white PLA and then glued together with super glue.

description.text:
My contribution to the spinner world. Dual spinner using 608 bearings, with "dragon tails" on the sides. For easy printing with no supports, the model is printed in 2 pieces and then glued together before inserting the bearings. Even with that, it's still a little tough to print. Make sure your bed is level and get a nice first layer, especially for the smaller parts of the tails. Also print at a high resolution... I used 0.2 layer height and the tails don't look great (the layers are pretty distinct). I would recommend 0.15 layer height or lower.

Note, I did not make caps for this spinner, so none are provided in the download. I just used some random caps I had, and you can find tons of other caps to print on thingiverse.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 or lower

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

Mine was printed in Hatchbox white PLA and then glued together with super glue.

I designed the main body of the spinner in Fusion 360. Then I imported it into Blender to create the tails and merge everything together. Finally, I used Meshmixer to cut the model in half and prepare it for printing.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 extruder cover - no wobble

description.text:
i found that my e3D v6 had a bit of wobble when i printed the supplied extruder cover.

so i took off the top 1mm, hoping to clamp down more on the hot end at the top, and also added a small "bump" at the bottom to help move the heated block away from the fan mount by a little bit (also to lessen the wobble) as i normally print ABS, its started to melt the fan mount

i printed this at 0.14mm layer heights with a 0.4mm nozzle at 100%, and it worked perfectly. my e3D is now rock solid with almost no movement at all.

title: Mini Maracas that Really Work!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I stretched out the shape of XYZAidan's 3D Printer Maracas a bit, joined two together and added a small loop at the top. I also made the entire maraca hollow and then shrunk it down to a tiny size. They can now be used for a variety of things, like a necklace, a keychain, earrings, hanging from a rearview mirror or even a Christmas Tree Ornament.

The coolest part is that even at only 32mm (1-1/4") across they still work, though you will have to hold them very close to your ear to hear anything. :)

While they were printing I put 3 grains of rice into each one. Make sure you print without any infill. They need to be hollow.

author: RayneMan

title: Low Voltage Ceiling Light For Camper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
currently working on updating the lighting in my trailer, I live in it full time and am preparing to go ff grid, so these will be eventually powered off of a pretty large sized 3.4V battery. each one takes 6 COB mounted star leds. which puts them at around 13.86W per assembly. they are attached with 3mm screws, i just happened to have a bunch of old computer case screws around but lowes sells 3mm x 5 mm which is about what you would need. i picked up the leds for a song something like 5$usd with the heatsinks for 50 pcs.

Update: 8/11/17 6:03am

Ok, I added a bunc more pictures to hopefully help explain why this design has so many holes in it... lol.

the holes in the side are to allow for routing of the wire, in my camper there is only so many places you would want a wire to go. I ended up printing 5 of these, one for the entry way one for over my printer, 2 for the middle of the room, and one for over the foot of the bed( as the head of the bed will have my later uploaded 4 way spot light like the one over my desk, or i may combine the two things into this thing as a sort of COB lighting suite.) the first middle of the room light works as a hub to send the wires out to the entryway light, the printer light, and the main lights. there are 4 holes in the dish on each side where the wire inlet/outlet holes are, this is so you can tack down the wire ends. I have used 4 conductor low voltage (telephone/alarm) wire, each conductor is rated at 7A, the red wire is used to power ALL the leds, the Black wire is used to Ground the entry way light, the green is used to ground the printer light, and the yellow grounds the rest of the main lights. 4 circuits in 1 cable. the picture of all of the lights is labeled to show the wire combination for each light (RY:Red/Yellow RB:Red/Black RG:Red/Green) the main hub light is the most crowded as far as wiring goes, it took a bit of effort to get all of the wires out of the way of the leds. I still need to design and print some sort of cable clam to secure the wire to the ceiling. i will probably do that next. The LEDs are connected in parallel using Bus wire, commonly bus wire is used for solar panels but i find that it is very handy for things like this as it is a flat wire that is pre tinned, which makes soldering a breeze, it took me an hour to solder all the leds together in their respective dishes, in contrast to the 2 hours it took to assemble them with the hold down screws, and orienting the leds so that they would not be shorted by the hold down screws, and further contrast to the 3.5 hours it took to mount them to the ceiling and wire them up. The center hole is a singular mounting hole so that you can attach them to the ceiling, because they are thin and my screws are long i had to use 6 4mm flat washers to move the housings off direct contact with the ceiling. the next thing on my to do list is to come up with a cover lens for them as even accidental eye contact leaves you with polka-dots in the eyes. All in all the light that comes off of them makes you feel like you are in a spiffy new model home. I am very happy with the results. i will update when the lenses are done. :)

-T

remixed_from.author: fredini
remixed_from.title: Scan-O-Tron Turntable v.2.0 for Full Body 3D Scanning

description.text:
This is a supplement / expansion project of the original, with accurate drawings for an updated Scan-O-Tron 3000 ... ( Still a work in progress )

Plan is to update the turntable with an attached box for motor & electronic equipment ...

Additional details to be added when they come to hand ...

This was drawn up in AutoCAD / SketchUp, with output files in Illustrator / PDF files.

Measurements were taken from various sources & will be made available on drawings later when I have confirmed they work.

Hardware :
  • 16mm Plywood sheet ( CNC cut )
  • Wheel Hub - Toyota ZZE122 ( http://www.alliedbearings.com.au/rear-wheel-bearing-hub-assembly-for-toyota-corolla )
  • Chain - Approx 600mm long ( I used one from Garage but same as Bicycle )
  • Feet ( 3d printed )
  • Various nuts & bolts ... ( more details to add )
Electrical :
  • Motor ( TBA )
  • Driver ( CNC board )
  • Sensor ?
  • Power supply
  • Various wiring
Software :

Working on controls for this ...

Provisionally see here : https://www.dfrobot.com/wiki/index.php/TMC260_Stepper_Motor_Driver_Shield_SKU:_DRI0035

https://www.trinamic.com/products/integrated-circuits/details/tmc260a-pa/

Once all the components are gathered together, start assembly with the lower base ...

  • Bolt on feet & lower race.

  • Fit Wheel Hub ( may need to ream / make holes to suit )

  • Fit upper turntable.

  • Chain gear.

  • Step Box.

  • Motor & Electronics.

( more details to add )

This is a prototype expansion of original turntable by Fred Kahl :
https://makezine.com/projects/guide-to-3d-printing-2014/heavy-duty-turntable/

++ Caution : The gap between turntable & step currently has no tolerance built it - so may bind without taking some off ... ( will fix this in next update )

First issue with draft drawings ... Aug 2017

Revised notes / drawings / images ... Nov 2017

Counter part to this :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476589

description.text:
I recently came across this instructable which features a really neat radius gauge set. Having already used a few gauges printed from Thingiverse, I knew this set would be more useful to me because they are so tiny.

We have used some of the measuring tools available out there, but we have found that most of them aren't suitable for tight spaces since they have a long handle that doesn't fit inside the piece we are trying to measure.
[...]
Each piece has the same radius on the inside and outside of the part, so you can measure both the inside or the outside corner radius of a part using the same piece.

The only thing that deterred me from downloading the set is having to download it from their website, where you are required to provide personal information in order to retrieve the files. This is a big no-no for me, so I decided to write a customizable OpenSCAD script to make the set accessible to download for everyone.

description.text:
Supplement to the Person Turntable :

Am in the process of making a fully automated vertical slide for the 3D Scanner - These additional parts are required to mount various bits onto a pole ...

See links below for more info ...

( More to add )

Taken various bits that were lying around & scrounged for additional parts. Missing Elements were drawn up in TinkerCAD & SketchUp ...

These things were made with Tinkercad :

  • https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dPWV0X2SQyh-pole-mount-spacer
  • https://www.tinkercad.com/things/goMyAFXFBxd-pulley-stopo
  • https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hXiaavAAnPK-spring-loaded-mount

SketchUp :

( More to Add )

Hardware :
  • Pole
  • Slide
  • Motor

• Revised info & add files ... Oct 2017
  • Add more info / Photos etc. ... Nov 2017

Collection of various bits & pieces to enable mounting of the Microsoft Kinetics camera to a pole. Most of these parts complement the use of a of 'static' pole, converting it into fully functioning vertical axis ...

( More to Add )

box_size = 100

This is just another low cost Spool Holder, this design fits standard 56mm spools down to 52mm, it requires 2 x 608ZZ ball bearings. The idea is to have a bunch of spools on a long threaded rod (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2512609).
The ball bearing hole was initially made tight so you need to use a pair of plier to pop it in (for the first version). It comes with a little spacer. I printed mine using PLA 1.75mm, 10% infill and a bit slower speed (50mm/s).

Update 1: Separated objects to different files, plus adding a spacer with gap to make removal easier.

Update 2: Removed the spacers which were too small, replaced with rod covers

Update 3: Redesigned the Spool Holder, this one is easier to put the ball bearings in and is more stable.

Update 4: Added a slightly larger version (59mm diameter) for larger spools.

Update 5: Added a 65mm version. By the way, there is a reason why there are 4 holes in the holder. A few cable ties will secure them in the spool, it's easier to mount/dismount those onto the rods. Also added the M8 spacers: full type for the end of rod, cut type to be snapped in the middle of the rod.

title: hair filter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: a hairfilter for the shower sink

My flatmate is normally to lazy to remove her hair, from the shower sink. So sometimes I am more or less taking a bath, cause of the blocked sink. I hope this will help... At least for me to remove these hair balls. It is fully parametric, as I was to lazy to measure the size of the sink till now. It will adapt the appropriate count of holes to the sink-size and the desired holesize. update: More fancy rounded edges. update: now prints in two parts. so no need for support anymore. You can print either print hairfilter_complete.stl with both parts almost in right position or hairfilter_inner_part.stl&hairfilter_outer_part.stl. Just snap both parts together afterwards.

comments.text: For me it worked well. But I changed the design. Just for you. :) Prints without any support in two parts now. The wall thickness is so low on purpose, in an earlier version i had thicker walls, these are harder to clean somehow.
comments.author: rrr

comments.text: This design has flaws. The inner wall of the cylinder is too thin and breaks during removing rafts and supports. Even though I printed with 4 shells and 100% infill with a raft and supports. The ring is the only durable thickness the rest needs revision to make it more thicker and durable.
comments.author: innomind

title: DeLonghi Magnifica S Bean tray extension 5cm

description.text:
The bean tray of the DeLonghi Magnifica S is small. Using this Thing you will get a bean tray that is 50mm higher, giving enough space to load a large bag of beans in one go.

  • No need to store an opened bag in your cupboard anymore;
  • Less frequently need to do a bean-refill.

The two smaller parts are optional:

  • The flat one is the lid for closing the top of the original lid.
  • The high one is for making a tunnel to the GrindedBeans lid, keeping it accessible. Set the GrindedBeans lid upright open and you can lower this part over the opened lid.

If you want, and since the front is flat, you can easily make your own customized version by adding any text in relief.

I have no pictures yet. If anyone has please upload them or send them to me.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Supports:

No

Notes:

This Thing is slightly too large for the Ultimaker 3 but with a little trick it will be possible to print it. I don't know this trick myself but will ask my printer-buddy to tell me.

Of course using any other slightly larger printer is an option too.
Built in Sketchup and Cura

title: Two Piece Snap-On Coffee Cup Valve Caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These cute little cups of coffee are made using a combination of 'normal' PLA and flexible filament, using their respective characteristics. The flexible coffee parts snap easily in place into the PLA printed cups. After that you simply press them onto your tire valves by pushing on the coffee part. Their flexibility provide a perfect grasp on the valves, as you can also see in the video.

TUTUGO's fit on all commonly used bicycle and car valves. Make sure you print the right version for yours. The cup is universal and can be used for all valve types, the coffee parts differ: There's one that fits both Presta (French) and Dunlop (Dutch or English) valves and there's one fitting Schrader (car or American) valves.

Happy drinking! Coffee that is .. as you still need to drive.


Cheers, Baschz



P.S. If you want to support me, you can buy a ready-to-go set in a hand pulled three colour screen printed packaging all made by me from my Etsy shop. It would help me a lot.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Q3CtkSW5jg

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini & Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2 mm

Infill:

Depending on your choice of flex filament

Notes:

Your settings might need to be different, but here are mine:

CUP printed in Das Filament white PLA on 200°C with a 50°C heated bed on the Monoprice Select Mini*. 100% infill. 0.1 mm layer height. Fan 100%.

Latte COFFEE printed upside down, slowly in Recreus FilaFlex Skin II on 230°C with a 40°C heated bed on the Creality CR-10. 100% infill (lines) so it is stiff enough. 0.2 mm layer height. Fan 20%. Minimal to no retraction. Initial layer pattern is set to Concentric* (in Cura) to better mimic coffee.

Black COFFEE printed upside down, slowly in Polymaker PolyFlex Black on 230°C with a 40°C heated bed on the Creality CR-10. 30% infill so it's not too stiff. 0.2 mm layer height. Fan 20%. Minimal to no retraction. Initial layer pattern is set to Concentric* (in Cura) to better mimic coffee.

*I have used both Mandy (Monoprice Select Mini) and CRIS (Creality CR-10) to print all pieces, so I don't exactly know which is which in the pictures anymore.

I have tried several flexible filaments on the market (far from all) and for this specific project I found the ones above to be working the best for me, stiffness and colour availability wise. I would love to hear your experience with other filaments, as well as the ones that I've used. It might take a few tries to get it right, as you can see from my different settings above. Good luck and I would love to see your prints!
Simply snap-fit the coffee part into the cup, then place them onto your valves by pressing on the coffee part and you're on your way!

All printed parts were designed in Autodesk Fusion 360.

Package design and logo were first drawn on paper, then scanned and further worked on in Adobe Photoshop. Then the three color layers were put on a screenprinting frame and screen printed by hand. Finished by cutting, folding, assembling and gluing.

In case you're wondering why the Schrader coffee part has a thin hole going up higher than the actual valve does. This is to give the top part extra rigidity, so it better snaps in place and stays there.

title: Anet A8 Titan Mount plus 18mm probe

description.text:
Original design had one problem in my mind, that there was no easy access to filament tightening screw of Titan extruder (problem shown in white printed part).

So I lifted the motor mount 22mm upwards which gave access to the screw (fix shown in printed red part). This also gives 22mm more print height on Z-axis.

Marlin defines that I'm using in the firmware:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -26 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 19 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

This is the Fan mount https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2344098

Updated V4 version adds some more holes, for example to use zip ties for securing cables through the holes and better height for belt screws.

title: Canon 18-55mm Lens to Meade MA 26mm & 9mm (1.25 inch) Eyepiece

description.text:
I used a round file to clean all the holes and then tapped to 3mm with a 0.5mm pitch. The screws used to connect the two halves of the part were 5mm in length, and the set screws used were 6mm in length. Using screws longer than 5mm to connect the two halves may result in damage to the camera lens. When assembling the part, check that the screws do not protrude into the camera lens area. Using a 5mm long machine screw should result in a flush finish on the inside of the part.

Once the two halves are together, the eyepiece can be inserted from the camera side until the eyepiece's rubber eyecup rests in the tapered area on the camera lens side.

WARNING: This next step may damage or leave marks on your eyepiece. Do not over tighten set screws. Continue at your own risk.

Hold in place with set screws (no need to over tighten, just enough to hold).

I found the camera had optimal focus when set to a zoom of 55, so to allow the auto focus to have enough room to move freely, set the lens to manual focus, set zoom to 55, and adjust focus so the lens is at its full length. Remove the lens cap and insert into the part.

WARNING: This next step may leave marks or dimples on the Canon 18-55mm camera lens zoom ring. Other models of camera lens may have other damage. Do not over tighten set screws. Continue at your own risk.

Hold in place with set screws. The part is designed with extra set screw holes, the Canon 18-55mm lens only needs the holes closest to the camera body.

Inset into telescope, adjust telescope focus, set camera to auto focus, and enjoy.

description.text:
After not finding a purge bucket for my sigma which I liked, to replace the metal stock buckets which rattle, I decided to create my own.

This was heavily influenced by another design from another site - however it did not print well, it had mesh errors for me which I couldn't fix, I couldn't even open the STL in Solidworks due to the many problems with it. Printing it came out semi-OK, however it did not fit the printer, and even things like the slot for the rubber, did not fit for me. So I decided to use it as a reference, but build a new part from scratch in Solidworks. So referencing the other design for those reasons.
Reference: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/bcn3d-sigma-wastebox

This is a LEFT side part, however mirroring it will make it work for the right side. My two sides of the printer were not 100% identical, however it still fits OK. I may make a dedicated right side part at some stage with minor adjustments, however this does fit fine.

Enjoy!

I hope this brings you non-rattling printing pleasure!

Included fairly high quality STL, and the Solidworks 2016 source file.

Printer Brand:

BCN3D

Printer:

BCN3D SIGMA

Rafts:

No

No

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used ABS, but PLA or other materials will be fine.
I did 3 layer walls, 5 bottom and 5 top layers.

Sliced with Simplify3D 4.0.0

Might need to rotate it in your slicer, so it sits on its bottom the right way up.

Hay everyone!

I`ve made a Runcam 3 cammount / holder for the Realacc x210 (not the pro one).

The mount is for the Runcam 3 rubbersuit by 4runner, you can find some more information and mounts there .

I love this system, if you have some more quads, you can simply switch the camera from one to another without any screws or pulling the cam out of the body.

So, i printed this with normal Pla (no flexible pla, tpu our ninjaflex, because I dont want a too loose mount) with 35% infill for a good stiffness and make it more durable for crashes. Wall thickness 0.8

Maybe you have to drill or grind the hole a little bigger, in my case it fits perfect.

Print it with support, like on the picture.

Another cool feature is you have access to the fpvcam cables by simply clicking out the mount.

Make sure to see my other designs, I created some more modifications for the realacc x210.

4-in-One Cleanbuild (VTX-Buzzer-LED-Receiver) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2713891

..and a (must have) VTX / Receiver - antenna holder mount because I broke my antenna in one of my first crashes. You can see it in some Pictures and also the broken antenna in the last picture: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2714205
Please let me know if you print one!

Have a nice day :)

title: Parametric Igus style linear bearing RJMP-01-xx and RJ4JP-01-xx in OpenSCAD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note that the file with the parametric bearing is updated in time; please add this design to your favorite collection or like the design to come back later and get the latest version. Please PM me if you encounter problems and I will fix them. Please share you print in the Make section.

This is a full parametric design for Igus RJMP-01-xx and RJ4JP-01-xx linear bearings. The design contains tables with data for these types of bearings; please adjust the parameters according to the bearing you want to print. A scale factor can be used to counteract the effects of shrinkage.

The design allows for custom designs. Extra long bearings can simply be made by changing the "extra bearing length" parameter and the mid section from the bearing glide surfaces can be removed or sized. This is very interesting for creating virtually play free linear bearings for the Prusa i3 concept printers with (printed) X-axis mounts that use the LM8LUU or LM8UU linear bearings.

This design is a further development of the design found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2464185.

I print these bearings from POM filament which is slick and very tough.

Edit 08-Sept-2017:
Extra long printed bearings work very well with the custom, parametric bearing housings from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2520976. I created extra long housings and bearings to replace the X-carriage bearings for a E3D modification.

Edit: 28-Sept-2017
Fixed 2 issues, chamfer boolean with value True set to false (capitals not allowed) and removed the accidental hard coded 8 in the shaft diameter.

Edit 20-Oct-2017
Reverted setting of total bearing length for custom long bearings, instead the extra length needs to be inserted due to the fact that variables are determined at compile time rather then run time.

print_settings.Infill:: PLA / 3 Shells / 35% or more infill at standard scale. Reduce when scaled up.

title: Minisaurs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Minisaurs are great fun and have a powerful bite with jaws that snap shut!

Well printed Minisaurs have jaws that will snap closed when you hold the tail and flick the legs and are great little helpers around home and / or in the workshop or office as a peg / clip / clamp. They have a huge bite relative to their size!

At standard scale Minisaurs will print at 75mm long... so are really small. This makes them just the right size to use as a fun key fob that can even be clipped onto things to hold your keys up. Well set up / precise machines will print Minisaurs well at this size and hey should be free to bite and snap their jaws straight off the build plate. If not, uniformly scale the Minisaur's file up a small amount (which will increase clearances) and the jaws will be free to move. If in doubt scale up uniformly by 5 - 10%... it will still be a small print.

Scale them up!

The posted file is the smallest size recommended for printing.... and they scale up great. 125...150...200% all work really well and the bigger you print them the stronger the bite and louder they snap their jaws. Make sure you always scale uniformly.

Minisaurs are a fully enclosed print that has an internal spring section. To make the spring action 'snap' use higher than usual shells and infill. At standard scale 3 shells / 35% or more infill is recommended. As you increase the size infill can be reduced.

Great fun to fidget with yourself... make the jaws snap... useful as a clip / clamp / peg... and also a novel gift.

Print in your favourite colors... and print lots. The Minisaur age has begun!

Refer to the print settings and images for additional information. And please post photos of your Minisaurs for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out he rest of my fun and practical designs.

As long as your machine is well set up / precise, has a filament fan and bridges well you should be able to print Minisuars without any issues an they will come off the build plate with jaws that snap closed (Remove raft and flick the legs while holding the tail).
Just remove the Raft and start snapping the jaws and biting things!

title: Anti-vibration feet V2 for GEEETech i3 Pro B with 8mm acrylic frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had designed some anti-vibration feet for the Geeetech i3 printers before, but these slowly started to sag and compress over time.
For the people that has these problems and for those that just want the better design right away I now have V2 which has a reinforcement bracket in the feet that give it extra strength but still makes sure these is almost no noise from the printer.

Still work best when combined with the Astrosyn Nema17 decouplers.

Printer:

Gemstock - Azurite

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print everything once, except for the front part, those are indicated with "Anti-Vibration Feet - Damper/Feet - FrontLR.stl".
These need to printed 2 times each, as the front parts are identical and are just "mounted" the other way around.

Assembly

Use M4x6mm nuts and bolts to fasten the feet together with the dampener.
Then just slide the part under the correct corners and you're ready to enjoy your audible difference in printer noise.

comments.text: I printed these and just wanted to say how good they are and what a massive difference they have made to the noise level from my printer. All you can hear now are the fans running. Anyone with a Geeetech I3 Pro B or any other compatible printer should print themselves a set.

description.text:
This is a simple enclosure to hold 3 4-way loudspeaker connectors and a toggle switch to provide a 2 in 1 out stereo switch to connect 2 audio amplifiers to one set of speakers. It can also be used to switch 1 amplifier between 2 sets of speakers.

In my case I am using this to allow switching between a surround sound amplifier and a bluetooth amplifier connected to an Echo Dot driving the rear surround speakers.

The SCAD file allows for printing the base, lid and an optional mounting plate. The plate is just a flat sheet attached to the switch so that I can hang the enclosure behind a piece f furniture and only the switch is visible.

There is enough room in the enclosure to put in a pair of miniature DPDT relays instead of the toggle switch if one wanted to make it remote controlled.
This is just a cool thing I designed, and I hope you like it!

I play bass guitar and having a 3D printed bass is something that is on my check-list.

The body of the guitar is based on multiple bass guitars around the web that I like and it uses the neck from a cheap Yamaha donor.

It wasn't a real success as the body did not have the strength to withstand the tension of the strings. However V2 is already underway which has reinforcements in the form of 10mm steel rods in the body so that it can be fully playable.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 Pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed with 5 walls, and 5 top/bottom layers.

description.text: Small stand to hold a long thin object.

So Had the idea that I wanted to be able to elevate characters on a map to show flying ect... Secondly I am working on a clip system so we can join them up to make stairs and platforms etc.

EDIT 15-Aug-2017: Updated the STL files, the base one was not working like i wanted, and I reduced the hole size slightly so it fits a 8mm rod snugly. Fairly happy now. I made a connector piece so you can link 3 in a row, but it was just terrible.

Still working on it and looking for feedback if anyone prints it and uses it.

The rod holding the two pieces together is 8mm wooden doweling from Bunnings in Australia (hardware store), if anyone wants ill upload a 8mm rod to print, however I found that just buying 1 or 2 of these lengths was far more economical and allows you to customise as much as you want.
